title: Fundamental Concept
subtitle: basic building blocks from which other structures are constructed

title: Set
subtitle: a collection of distinct elements considered as a single entity

title: Relation
subtitle: a subset of a Cartesian product specifying correspondences between elements

title: Number
subtitle: an abstract representation of quantity, magnitude, or position in a sequence

title: Function
subtitle: a mapping assigning each element of one set to a unique element of another set

title: Tuple
subtitle: an ordered finite sequence of elements

title: Operation
subtitle: a rule for combining elements of sets to produce elements

title: Proposition / Predicate
subtitle: a statement or condition that may be true or false.

title: Mathematical Proposition
subtitle: A proposition within a formal mathematical system.

title: Mathematical Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical proposition that has been proven to be true based on a set of axioms and rules of inference.

title: Geometric Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning geometric figures, spaces, or properties.

title: Pythagorean Theorem
subtitle: A geometric theorem stating that in a right-angled triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides.

title: Thales's Theorem
subtitle: An angle inscribed in a semicircle is a right angle.

title: Euclid's Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
subtitle: While about primes, its original proof by Euclid is often considered geometric in flavor, but perhaps better under Number-Theoretic. Let's stick to more purely geometric ones for now. Self-correction: This is more number theory.

title: Angle Sum Theorem for Triangles
subtitle: The sum of the angles in a Euclidean triangle is 180 degrees or \(\pi\) radians.

title: Pons Asinorum (Isosceles Triangle Theorem)
subtitle: If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite them are equal.

title: Apollonius's Theorem
subtitle: Relates the length of a median of a triangle to the lengths of its sides.

title: Ptolemy's Theorem
subtitle: Relates the four sides and two diagonals of a cyclic quadrilateral.

title: Ceva's Theorem
subtitle: Concerns the condition for concurrency of cevians in a triangle.

title: Menelaus's Theorem
subtitle: Concerns the condition for collinearity of points on the sides (or their extensions) of a triangle.

title: Heron's Formula (as a theorem)
subtitle: A theorem stating that the area of a triangle whose sides have lengths \(a, b, c\) is \(\sqrt{s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)}\) where \(s\) is the semi-perimeter. The formula itself is an expression, but the statement that it correctly gives the area is a theorem.

title: Euler's Theorem in Geometry
subtitle: Relates the distance between the circumcenter and incenter of a triangle to the radii of the circumcircle and incircle: \(d^2 = R(R-2r)\).

title: Desargues's Theorem
subtitle: A theorem in projective geometry concerning two triangles in perspective.

title: Pappus's Hexagon Theorem
subtitle: A theorem in projective geometry concerning collinearity of intersection points of lines.

title: Pascal's Theorem
subtitle: If an arbitrary hexagon is inscribed in any conic section, then the three pairs of opposite sides meet in three collinear points.

title: Brianchon's Theorem
subtitle: The dual of Pascal's theorem; if a hexagon is circumscribed about a conic section, its main diagonals are concurrent.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Projective Geometry
subtitle: States that a projectivity is uniquely determined by its action on three points.

title: Pick's Theorem
subtitle: Relates the area of a simple polygon whose vertices are integer lattice points to the number of interior and boundary lattice points.

title: Gauss-Bonnet Theorem
subtitle: Relates the curvature of a surface to its topology (Euler characteristic).

title: Cauchy's Rigidity Theorem for Polyhedra
subtitle: Convex polyhedra with congruent corresponding faces are congruent.

title: Triangle Inequality Theorem
subtitle: The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle must be greater than or equal to the length of the third side.

title: Exterior Angle Theorem
subtitle: The measure of an exterior angle of a triangle is greater than either of the measures of the remote interior angles, or equal to their sum in Euclidean geometry.

title: Power of a Point Theorem
subtitle: For a given point P and a circle, for any line through P intersecting the circle at A and B, the product PA·PB is constant.

title: Simson Line Theorem
subtitle: For any point P on the circumcircle of a triangle ABC, the feet of the perpendiculars from P to the sides of the triangle are collinear.

title: Butterfly Theorem
subtitle: A theorem concerning properties of chords and a point on a chord within a circle.

title: Napoleon's Theorem
subtitle: If equilateral triangles are constructed on the sides of any triangle, the centers of those equilateral triangles themselves form an equilateral triangle.

title: Morley's Trisector Theorem
subtitle: In any triangle, the three points of intersection of the adjacent angle trisectors form an equilateral triangle.

title: Number-Theoretic Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the properties and relationships of numbers, especially integers.

title: Euclid's Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
subtitle: States that there are infinitely many prime numbers.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
subtitle: States that every integer greater than 1 either is a prime number itself or can be represented as a product of prime numbers, and this representation is unique up to the order of the factors.

title: Fermat's Little Theorem
subtitle: States that if \(p\) is a prime number, then for any integer \(a\) not divisible by \(p\), \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\).

title: Chinese Remainder Theorem
subtitle: Provides conditions under which a system of simultaneous congruences has a unique solution modulo the product of the moduli.

title: Wilson's Theorem
subtitle: States that a natural number \(n > 1\) is a prime number if and only if \((n-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod{n}\).

title: Euler's Totient Theorem (Fermat-Euler Theorem)
subtitle: States that if \(n\) and \(a\) are coprime positive integers, then \(a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\), where \(\phi(n)\) is Euler's totient function.

title: Lagrange's Four-Square Theorem
subtitle: States that every natural number can be represented as the sum of four integer squares.

title: Quadratic Reciprocity Law
subtitle: Relates the solvability of \(x^2 \equiv p \pmod{q}\) to the solvability of \(x^2 \equiv q \pmod{p}\) for distinct odd primes \(p\) and \(q\).

title: Prime Number Theorem
subtitle: Describes the asymptotic distribution of the prime numbers among the positive integers.

title: Dirichlet's Theorem on Arithmetic Progressions
subtitle: States that for any two coprime integers \(a\) and \(d\), there are infinitely many primes of the form \(a + nd\), where \(n\) is a non-negative integer.

title: Thue-Siegel-Roth Theorem
subtitle: A result on Diophantine approximation of algebraic numbers.

title: Fermat's Last Theorem
subtitle: States that no three positive integers \(a, b, c\) can satisfy the equation \(a^n + b^n = c^n\) for any integer value of \(n\) greater than 2.

title: Algebraic Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning algebraic structures (like groups, rings, fields, vector spaces) and their properties.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
subtitle: States that every non-constant single-variable polynomial with complex coefficients has at least one complex root.

title: Lagrange's Theorem (Group Theory)
subtitle: States that for any finite group G, the order (number of elements) of every subgroup H of G divides the order of G.

title: Cayley's Theorem
subtitle: States that every group G is isomorphic to a subgroup of the symmetric group acting on G.

title: Isomorphism Theorems (for groups, rings, modules)
subtitle: Describe the relationship between quotients, homomorphisms, and substructures.

title: Sylow Theorems
subtitle: Provide detailed information about the number of subgroups of a fixed prime power order in a finite group.

title: Hilbert's Basis Theorem
subtitle: States that if R is a Noetherian ring, then the polynomial ring R[x] is also a Noetherian ring.

title: Abel-Ruffini Theorem
subtitle: States that there is no general algebraic solution (solution in radicals) for polynomial equations of degree five or higher.

title: Galois Theory Main Theorem
subtitle: Establishes a correspondence between subgroups of the Galois group of an extension and intermediate fields.

title: Rank-Nullity Theorem (Linear Algebra)
subtitle: States that for a linear map \(T: V \to W\), the dimension of V is the sum of the dimension of the kernel of T and the dimension of the image of T.

title: Spectral Theorem (Linear Algebra)
subtitle: Provides conditions under which a linear operator or matrix can be diagonalized.

title: Analytic Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning concepts from mathematical analysis, such as limits, continuity, derivatives, integrals, and infinite series.

title: Intermediate Value Theorem
subtitle: States that if a continuous function, \(f\), with an interval, \([a, b]\), as its domain, takes values \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\) at each end of the interval, then it also takes any value between \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\) at some point within the interval.

title: Extreme Value Theorem
subtitle: States that if a real-valued function \(f\) is continuous on a closed interval \([a, b]\), then \(f\) must attain a maximum and a minimum, each at least once.

title: Mean Value Theorem
subtitle: States that for a given planar arc between two endpoints, there is at least one point at which the tangent to the arc is parallel to the secant through its endpoints.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
subtitle: Relates differentiation and integration, showing that these two operations are essentially inverses of each other.

title: Taylor's Theorem
subtitle: Gives an approximation of a k-times differentiable function around a given point by a polynomial of degree k, called the Taylor polynomial.

title: Cauchy's Integral Theorem (Complex Analysis)
subtitle: States that for a holomorphic function defined on a simply connected domain, the line integral over a closed path in the domain is zero.

title: Residue Theorem (Complex Analysis)
subtitle: A powerful tool to evaluate line integrals of analytic functions over closed curves; it can often be used to compute real integrals as well.

title: Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem
subtitle: States that every bounded sequence in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) has a convergent subsequence.

title: Heine-Borel Theorem
subtitle: States that for a subset of Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^n\), compactness is equivalent to being closed and bounded.

title: Riemann Mapping Theorem
subtitle: States that any non-empty simply connected open subset of the complex plane (which is not the entire plane) is biholomorphically equivalent to the open unit disk.

title: Dominated Convergence Theorem
subtitle: Provides sufficient conditions under which limits of sequences of integrable functions commute with the integral sign.

title: Inverse Function Theorem
subtitle: Gives sufficient conditions for a function to be invertible in a neighborhood of a point in its domain, and also gives a formula for the derivative of the inverse function.

title: Calculus Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem specifically foundational to or derived within the field of Calculus, concerning concepts such as limits, derivatives, integrals, and series.

title: Rolle's Theorem
subtitle: A special case of the Mean Value Theorem, stating that for a differentiable function taking equal values at two distinct points, there is at least one point between them where the first derivative is zero.

title: L'Hôpital's Rule
subtitle: Provides a method for evaluating indeterminate forms of limits by taking the derivatives of the numerator and denominator.

title: Squeeze Theorem (Sandwich Theorem)
subtitle: States that if two functions "squeeze" a third function between them, and the two outer functions converge to the same limit, then the inner function must also converge to that same limit.

title: Weierstrass M-test
subtitle: A theorem that provides a sufficient condition for a series of functions to converge uniformly.

title: Fubini's Theorem
subtitle: Gives conditions under which it is possible to compute a multiple integral by iterated integration.

title: Green's Theorem
subtitle: Relates a line integral around a simple closed curve to a double integral over the plane region bounded by the curve.

title: Stokes' Theorem
subtitle: Relates the integral of a curl of a vector field over a surface to the line integral of the vector field over the boundary of the surface.

title: Divergence Theorem (Gauss's Theorem)
subtitle: Relates the flow of a vector field through a closed surface to the sum of the divergences of the field within the enclosed volume.

title: Chain Rule Theorem
subtitle: A formula to compute the derivative of a composite function.

title: Product Rule Theorem
subtitle: A formula to compute the derivative of a product of two or more functions.

title: Quotient Rule Theorem
subtitle: A formula to compute the derivative of a ratio of two functions.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals (Gradient Theorem)
subtitle: States that a line integral through a conservative vector field can be evaluated by finding the potential function at the endpoints.

title: Combinatorial Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the study of finite or countable discrete structures, including enumeration, existence, construction, and optimization.

title: Pigeonhole Principle
subtitle: States that if \(n\) items are put into \(m\) containers, with \(n > m\), then at least one container must contain more than one item.

title: Ramsey's Theorem
subtitle: In its simplest form, states that in any sufficiently large complete graph whose edges are colored with two colors (e.g., red and blue), one can find a monochromatic complete subgraph of a given size.

title: Hall's Marriage Theorem
subtitle: Provides a condition for the existence of a system of distinct representatives for a collection of finite sets.

title: Dilworth's Theorem
subtitle: Relates the width of a finite partially ordered set to a minimum chain decomposition.

title: Sperner's Theorem
subtitle: Describes the maximum size of an antichain in the power set of a finite set.

title: Turan's Theorem
subtitle: A result in extremal graph theory about the maximum number of edges in a graph not containing a complete graph \(K_r\) as a subgraph.

title: Burnside's Lemma (Orbit-Counting Theorem)
subtitle: Relates the number of orbits of a group action on a set to the number of fixed points of each group element.

title: Max-Flow Min-Cut Theorem
subtitle: States that in a flow network, the maximum flow passing from a source to a sink is equal to the minimum capacity of a cut separating the source from the sink.

title: Four Color Theorem
subtitle: States that any map in a plane can be colored using four or fewer colors in such a way that no two adjacent regions have the same color.

title: Van der Waerden's Theorem
subtitle: States that for any given positive integers \(r\) and \(k_1, \dots, k_r\), there is some number \(W(r; k_1, \dots, k_r)\) such that if the integers \(\{1, 2, \dots, W\}\) are colored, each with one of \(r\) different colors, then there must exist a monochromatic arithmetic progression of length \(k_i\) for some \(i \in \{1, \dots, r\}\).

title: Topological Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning properties of topological spaces that are invariant under continuous deformations (homeomorphisms).

title: Brouwer Fixed-Point Theorem
subtitle: States that for any continuous function \(f\) mapping a compact convex set into itself, there is a point \(x_0\) such that \(f(x_0) = x_0\).

title: Tychonoff's Theorem
subtitle: States that the product of any collection of compact topological spaces is compact with respect to the product topology.

title: Urysohn's Lemma
subtitle: States that in a normal topological space, any two disjoint closed sets can be separated by a continuous function.

title: Tietze Extension Theorem
subtitle: States that continuous functions defined on a closed subset of a normal topological space can be extended to the entire space.

title: Baire Category Theorem
subtitle: Provides sufficient conditions for a topological space to be a Baire space, meaning that the intersection of countably many dense open sets is dense.

title: Jordan Curve Theorem
subtitle: States that every simple closed curve (a Jordan curve) separates the plane into an "interior" region bounded by the curve and an "exterior" region containing all of the nearby and far away exterior points.

title: Hairy Ball Theorem
subtitle: States that there is no nonvanishing continuous tangent vector field on an even-dimensional n-sphere. Informally, "you can't comb a hairy ball flat without creating a cowlick."

title: Seifert-van Kampen Theorem
subtitle: Expresses the fundamental group of a topological space \(X\) which is the union of two path-connected open subspaces in terms of the fundamental groups of the subspaces and their intersection.

title: Classification of Surfaces Theorem
subtitle: States that any compact, connected 2-manifold is homeomorphic to a sphere, a connected sum of tori, or a connected sum of projective planes.

title: Set-Theoretic Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the properties of sets, often within a specific axiomatic system like ZFC.

title: Cantor's Theorem
subtitle: States that the cardinality of the power set of any set A is strictly greater than the cardinality of A.

title: Schroeder-Bernstein Theorem
subtitle: States that if there exist injective functions \(f: A \to B\) and \(g: B \to A\) between sets A and B, then there exists a bijective function \(h: A \to B\).

title: Zorn's Lemma
subtitle: States that a partially ordered set containing upper bounds for every chain (i.e., every totally ordered subset) necessarily contains at least one maximal element. (Equivalent to Axiom of Choice)

title: Well-Ordering Theorem
subtitle: States that every set can be well-ordered. (Equivalent to Axiom of Choice)

title: Continuum Hypothesis (Statement as a theorem within models)
subtitle: The proposition that there is no set whose cardinality is strictly between that of the integers and that of the real numbers. (Its truth is independent of ZFC).

title: Cantor-Bendixson Theorem
subtitle: States that every closed subset of a Polish space is the union of a perfect set and a countable set.

title: Probabilistic Theorem
subtitle: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the formal study of probability, random variables, and stochastic processes.

title: Law of Large Numbers (LLN)
subtitle: Describes the result of performing the same experiment a large number of times. According to the law, the average of the results obtained from a large number of trials should be close to the expected value and will tend to become closer as more trials are performed.

title: Weak Law of Large Numbers
subtitle: (WLLN)

title: Strong Law of Large Numbers
subtitle: (SLLN)

title: Central Limit Theorem (CLT)
subtitle: States that, under certain conditions, the sum (or average) of a large number of independent and identically distributed random variables, each with finite mean and variance, will be approximately normally distributed.

title: Bayes' Theorem
subtitle: Describes the probability of an event, based on prior knowledge of conditions that might be related to the event.

title: Borel-Cantelli Lemmas
subtitle: Results in probability theory concerning sequences of events.

title: Kolmogorov's Zero-One Law
subtitle: States that any event in the tail \(\sigma\)-algebra of a sequence of independent random variables has probability 0 or 1.

title: Martingale Convergence Theorem
subtitle: Provides conditions under which a martingale (or submartingale/supermartingale) converges almost surely or in \(L^p\).

title: Logical Theorem (Metatheorem)
subtitle: A mathematical theorem about formal logical systems themselves, such as their consistency, completeness, or decidability. (Distinguished from theorems *within* a specific logic, which would be classified under that logic if it were a branch of mathematics like Boolean Algebra).

title: Gödel's Completeness Theorem (First-Order Logic)
subtitle: States that a first-order sentence is provable from a set of axioms if and only if it is logically valid (true in every model of the axioms).

title: First Incompleteness Theorem
subtitle: States that in any consistent formal system F within which a certain amount of arithmetic can be carried out, there are statements of the language of F which can neither be proved nor disproved in F.

title: Second Incompleteness Theorem
subtitle: States that such a formal system cannot prove its own consistency.

title: Compactness Theorem (First-Order Logic)
subtitle: States that a set of first-order sentences has a model if and only if every finite subset of it has a model.

title: Löwenheim-Skolem Theorem
subtitle: States that if a countable first-order theory has an infinite model, then for every infinite cardinal \(\kappa\) it has a model of size \(\kappa\).

title: Church-Turing Thesis (as a formal statement within computability theory)
subtitle: While not a theorem in the mathematical sense (it's a hypothesis about the nature of computation), its formal counterparts relating different models of computation (e.g., Turing machines and lambda calculus) are theorems.

title: Tarski's Undefinability Theorem
subtitle: States that arithmetical truth cannot be defined in arithmetic.

title: Craig's Interpolation Theorem
subtitle: States that if \(\phi \models \psi\) is a valid entailment in first-order logic, then there exists an interpolant sentence \(\chi\) whose non-logical symbols occur in both \(\phi\) and \(\psi\), such that \(\phi \models \chi\) and \(\chi \models \psi\).

title: Empirical Proposition
subtitle: A statement whose truth value is determined by observation, experience, or scientific investigation of the physical or social world.

title: Scientific Hypothesis
subtitle: A proposed explanation for a phenomenon, which can be tested through experimentation or observation.

title: Scientific Law (Empirical)
subtitle: A descriptive generalization about how the natural world behaves under stated circumstances, based on repeated empirical observations.

title: Normative Proposition
subtitle: A statement that expresses a value judgment, a prescription, or a rule about how things should be, rather than how they are.

title: Ethical Proposition
subtitle: A statement concerning moral rightness or wrongness, good or bad, duty or obligation.

title: Legal Proposition
subtitle: A statement within a legal system that prescribes, permits, or prohibits actions, or defines rights and obligations.

title: Definition
subtitle: A statement that explains the meaning of a word, phrase, or concept, often by specifying its essential qualities or properties.

title: Lexical
subtitle: A definition that explains how a term is actually used by speakers of a language.

title: English Lexical
subtitle: A lexical definition for a term as used in the English language.

title: Mathematical Field/System
subtitle: A distinct branch or area of study within mathematics, characterized by a coherent set of concepts, theories, methods, and problems.

title: Algebra
subtitle: The branch of mathematics dealing with symbols and the rules for manipulating these symbols in formulas; it serves as a unifying thread of almost all of mathematics.

title: Geometry
subtitle: The branch of mathematics concerned with the properties and relations of points, lines, surfaces, solids, and higher dimensional analogs.

title: Topology
subtitle: The branch of mathematics concerned with the properties of geometric objects that are preserved under continuous deformations, such as stretching, twisting, crumpling, and bending, but not tearing or gluing.

title: Analysis
subtitle: The branch of mathematics dealing with limits and related theories, such as differentiation, integration, measure, infinite series, and analytic functions.

title: Calculus
subtitle: A fundamental branch of mathematics focusing on rates of change and accumulation, built upon the concepts of limits, derivatives, integrals, and infinite series.

title: Differential Calculus
subtitle: The branch of calculus concerned with the study of the rates at which quantities change.

title: Integral Calculus
subtitle: The branch of calculus concerned with the study of accumulation of quantities and the areas under curves.

title: Multivariable Calculus
subtitle: The extension of calculus to functions of more than one variable.

title: Vector Calculus
subtitle: A branch of mathematics concerned with differentiation and integration of vector fields.

title: Real Analysis
subtitle: The branch of mathematical analysis dealing with real numbers and real-valued functions of a real variable.

title: Complex Analysis
subtitle: The branch of mathematical analysis that investigates functions of complex numbers.

title: Functional Analysis
subtitle: A branch of mathematical analysis, the core of which is formed by the study of vector spaces endowed with some kind of limit-related structure (e.g. inner product, norm, topology).

title: Harmonic Analysis

title: Informational
subtitle: Abstract patterns, structures, and meaning

title: Information Kind
subtitle: A fundamental category or type of information based on its intrinsic nature, modality, or primary purpose.

title: Natural Language Written
subtitle: Information primarily encoded in a natural human language using a writing system, intended primarily for human comprehension, communication, and expression.

title: Narrative
subtitle: Natural language written information primarily structured to recount a sequence of events, whether real or imagined, often involving characters, setting, and plot. (Novels, short stories, epic poems, biographies, memoirs, historical accounts, narrative news features.)

title: Expository or Documentary
subtitle: Natural language written information primarily intended to explain, describe, define, inform, or clarify a subject or concept based on facts and evidence. (Factual news reports, most sections of scientific papers, textbooks, essays that explain, technical documentation.)

title: Argumentative
subtitle: Natural language written information primarily intended to present a reasoned case for a particular viewpoint, to persuade the reader, or to debate an issue. (Editorials, opinion pieces, critical reviews, persuasive essays, legal briefs, the discussion/conclusion sections of scientific papers.)

title: Descriptive
subtitle: Natural language written information primarily focused on conveying sensory details and characteristics to create a vivid impression of a person, place, object, or experience. (Detailed character sketches, travelogues.)

title: Procedural
subtitle: Natural language written information primarily intended to provide instructions, directions, or steps for performing a task or achieving a specific outcome. (Recipes, instruction manuals, how-to guides, experimental methods sections in scientific papers, user guides.)

title: Lyrical
subtitle: Natural language written information, often in poetic form, primarily focused on expressing personal emotions, subjective experiences, observations, or reflections, frequently characterized by figurative language and rhythmic qualities. (Lyric poems, song lyrics (as text), personal reflective essays.)

title: Dialogic
subtitle: Natural language written information primarily representing conversation, direct speech, or an exchange between two or more entities. (Scripts for plays or screenplays (the dialogue), interview transcripts, quoted conversations.)

title: Audio
subtitle: Information primarily encoded for auditory perception.

title: Speech
subtitle: Audio information consisting primarily of spoken human language, intended to convey linguistic meaning. (Audiobooks, podcasts (the speech content), recorded lectures, voice messages, dialogue tracks from films when isolated.)

title: Musical
subtitle: Audio information characterized by organized sound patterns, including elements such as melody, harmony, rhythm, and timbre, typically created for aesthetic, cultural, or expressive purposes. (Songs (vocal or instrumental), symphonies, instrumental pieces, jingles, film scores.)

title: Environmental Sound
subtitle: Audio information consisting of sounds originating from the natural or artificial environment, not primarily categorized as speech or music, often capturing the acoustic character of a place or event. (Recordings of birdsong, city traffic sounds, ocean waves, wind, machinery hum, footsteps, applause.)

title: Abstract or Generated Sound
subtitle: Audio information composed of sounds that are primarily synthesized, heavily processed, or do not directly represent recognizable real-world events, speech, or conventional music, often used for sound design, signaling, or experimental art. (Sound effects (e.g., a laser blast, a synthesized alert tone), some forms of electronic or experimental sound art, sonic textures not classifiable as music or environmental sound.)

title: Audiovisual
subtitle: Information that intrinsically integrates both dynamic visual and audio elements for a combined perceptual experience.

title: Narrative
subtitle: Audiovisual information primarily structured to recount a sequence of events, whether real or imagined, often involving characters, setting, plot, and dialogue, where both visual and audio components contribute to the storytelling. (Feature films, fictional television series, animated series/cartoons, narrative short films, cinematic video game cutscenes.)

title: Expository or Documentary
subtitle: Audiovisual information primarily intended to explain, describe, inform, document, or clarify a subject, event, or concept, using a combination of visuals and audio. (Documentaries, news reports (video segments), educational videos, instructional videos, video essays.)

title: Performative
subtitle: Audiovisual information primarily capturing a live or staged performance, where the visual depiction of the performers and the accompanying audio of the performance are integral. (Recordings of concerts, theatrical plays, dance performances, operas, stand-up comedy specials.)

title: Interactive
subtitle: Audiovisual information where the user's input directly influences the sequence, content, or presentation of the combined visual and audio elements in real-time. (Video games (the gameplay experience itself), interactive films, some forms of interactive art installations.)

title: Promotional or Persuasive
subtitle: Audiovisual information primarily designed to promote a product, service, idea, or individual, or to persuade the audience towards a particular viewpoint or action, using integrated visual and audio techniques. (Television commercials, film trailers, political advertisements (video), public service announcements (video), corporate promotional videos.)

title: Ambient or Atmospheric
subtitle: Audiovisual information primarily intended to create a specific mood, atmosphere, or sensory experience, where narrative or explicit informational content may be secondary to the aesthetic interplay of visuals and sound. (Some forms of video art, visualizers accompanying music where the visuals are tightly coupled, some types of screensavers or digital art installations with sound.)        2.1.5 Spatial - Content of spatial information (Blueprints, Architectural drawings, Maps).

title: Sheet Music
subtitle: Information primarily encoded using a standardized visual notation system to represent musical parameters (such as pitch, rhythm, harmony, dynamics, and timbre) intended for performance, study, analysis, or preservation of musical works.

title: Source Code
subtitle: Information encoded as a sequence of statements and declarations in a formal programming language, intended to be translated or executed by a computer to define the behavior of a computational system or to perform specific tasks. (e.g., a Python script, a C++ program file, an HTML document's textual content).

title: Temporal Structure Specification (Calendaring System)
subtitle: A formal system or abstract model defining the organization, measurement, and representation of time, typically involving cycles like days, months, and years.

title: Astronomical Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system primarily based on the observation or calculation of astronomical cycles (solar, lunar, or sidereal).

title: Solar Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system whose dates indicate the position of the Earth on its revolution around the Sun.

title: Gregorian Calendar
subtitle: The most widely used civil calendar in the world, a solar calendar with 365 days in a common year and 366 days in a leap year.

title: Julian Calendar
subtitle: A solar calendar introduced by Julius Caesar in 45 BC, which was the predominant calendar in the Roman world and later in most of Europe until it was replaced by the Gregorian calendar.

title: Ancient Egyptian Calendar
subtitle: An early solar calendar with 365 days, known for its consistent length and use of a 30-day month structure.

title: Baha'i Calendar
subtitle: A solar calendar with 19 months of 19 days each, plus an intercalary period of 'Ayyám-i-Há'.

title: Indian National Calendar (Saka Calendar)
subtitle: The official civil calendar of India, a solar calendar used alongside the Gregorian calendar.

title: Thai Solar Calendar
subtitle: The current calendar in Thailand, based on the Gregorian calendar but using the Buddhist Era.

title: Lunar Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system whose dates indicate the phase of the Moon, typically not adjusted to the solar year, causing its seasons to drift.

title: Islamic Calendar (Hijri Calendar)
subtitle: A purely lunar calendar with 12 lunar months, used in many Muslim countries for religious purposes.

title: Lunisolar Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system that combines both lunar and solar cycles to determine date, typically by adding an intercalary month periodically.

title: Hebrew Calendar
subtitle: A lunisolar calendar used predominantly for Jewish religious observances.

title: Hindu Calendars
subtitle: A diverse group of lunisolar calendars used in India for religious and civil purposes, varying by region.

title: Traditional Chinese Calendar
subtitle: A lunisolar calendar that determines traditional Chinese holidays and agricultural activities.

title: Buddhist Calendars
subtitle: Various lunisolar calendars used across Southeast Asian countries for religious purposes (e.g., Thai Lunar Calendar, Burmese Calendar).

title: Ancient Greek Calendars (e.g., Attic Calendar)
subtitle: Various city-state specific lunisolar calendars used in ancient Greece, often aligning lunar months with the solar year for civic and religious festivals.

title: Maya Calendar (Tzolkin and Haab' Long Count)
subtitle: A complex system including a 260-day ritual calendar (Tzolkin) and a 365-day civil calendar (Haab'), which interlock within a longer count.

title: Aztec Calendar (Xiuhpohualli and Tonalpohualli)
subtitle: A system similar to the Maya, with a 365-day solar calendar (Xiuhpohualli) and a 260-day ritual calendar (Tonalpohualli).

title: Inca Calendar
subtitle: A lunisolar calendar used by the Inca Empire, incorporating both solar and lunar observations for agricultural and religious purposes.

title: Cherokee Calendar
subtitle: A traditional lunisolar calendaring system used by the Cherokee people, tied to the cycles of the moon and solar events, often with month names reflecting agricultural or natural phenomena.

title: Sidereal Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system based on the sidereal year, which measures the Earth's orbital period with respect to the fixed stars.

title: Astronomical Sidereal Calendar
subtitle: Calendars used in astronomy based on Earth's true orbital period relative to distant stars, not the sun's apparent position.

title: Practical/Applied Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system designed for specific administrative, professional, or specialized temporal organization, not solely dependent on astronomical cycles.

title: Fiscal Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system used for business or financial reporting, often not aligned with standard astronomical years (e.g., a fiscal year starting July 1).

title: Academic Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system used by educational institutions to schedule terms, semesters, and holidays.

title: Ecclesiastical Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system used by religious denominations to organize their liturgical year, feasts, and fasts (e.g., Christian Liturgical Calendar, specific denominational calendars).

title: Broadcasting Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system used in media for scheduling television seasons, advertising periods, etc.

title: Sports League Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system used by sports organizations to schedule seasons, games, and playoffs.

title: Geological/Scientific Time Scale
subtitle: A hierarchical system of chronological dating that relates geological strata (stratigraphy) to time, used by Earth scientists to describe the timing and relationships of events in Earth history.

title: International Chronostratigraphic Chart
subtitle: The standard global geological time scale, managed by the International Commission on Stratigraphy.

title: Conceptual/Theoretical Calendar System
subtitle: A calendaring system proposed for theoretical or reform purposes, or as a simplified model, not necessarily in wide practical use.

title: French Republican Calendar
subtitle: A solar calendar proposed during the French Revolution, based on a decimal system, though short-lived.

title: Soviet Revolutionary Calendar
subtitle: A calendar used in the Soviet Union for a period, attempting to implement five- or six-day weeks and disrupting traditional cycles.

title: World Calendar
subtitle: A proposed calendar reform designed to be perpetual, with fixed dates for holidays and quarters.

title: Hanke-Henry Permanent Calendar
subtitle: A proposed calendar reform designed to be perpetual, with a regular 364-day year and an extra week every five or six years.

title: Information Characteristic Type
subtitle: An intrinsic or ascribed characteristic, quality, or attribute of information or informational constructs.

title: Information Assurance Characteristic Type
subtitle: Concepts safeguarding information properties.

title: Confidentiality Characteristic Type
subtitle: Information secrecy principle.

title: Integrity Characteristic Type
subtitle: Information trustworthiness principle.

title: Availability Characteristic Type
subtitle: Information accessibility principle.

title: Authenticity Characteristic Type
subtitle: Information genuineness principle.

title: Non-Repudiation Characteristic Type
subtitle: Information action accountability.

title: Trustworthiness Characteristic Type
subtitle: Information system reliance.

title: Information Pragmatic Characteristic Type
subtitle: Aspects of information use/interpretation.

title: Pragmatic Function Characteristic Type
subtitle: Concept of information's purpose.

title: Contextuality Characteristic Type
subtitle: Concept of information context.

title: Intentionality Characteristic Type
subtitle: Concept of information intent.

title: Feedback Potential Characteristic Type
subtitle: Concept of information feedback.

title: Controllability Characteristic Type
subtitle: Concept of information control.

title: Information Unit Characteristic Type
subtitle: A classification of fundamental units used to compose or measure information.

title: Symbolic Information Unit Characteristic Type
subtitle: Type of unit based on symbols (e.g., character, grapheme).

title: Semantic Information Unit Characteristic Type
subtitle: Type of unit based on meaning (e.g., proposition, lexeme).

title: Quantitative Information Unit Characteristic Type
subtitle: Type of unit for measuring information quantity (e.g., bit, nat).

title: Information Operation (Abstract)
subtitle: Abstract actions on information.

title: Information Transformation Operation (Abstract)
subtitle: Abstract data conversion/change.

title: Information Analysis Operation (Abstract)
subtitle: Abstract pattern finding/analysis.

title: Information Interpretation Operation (Abstract)
subtitle: Abstract meaning extraction/decoding.

title: Information Generation Operation (Abstract)
subtitle: Abstract information synthesis/creation.

title: Information Filtering Operation (Abstract)
subtitle: Abstract information selection/reduction.

title: Physical
subtitle: The fundamental domain of tangible reality and its characteristics within space-time

title: Physical Entity
subtitle: discrete objects or continuous existences

title: Physical Substance
subtitle: homogeneous materials

title: Subatomic Particle
subtitle: fundamental constituent of matter and energy.

title: Fermion
subtitle: A kind of elementary particle that are constituents of matter, obey Fermi-Dirac statistics, and have half-integer spin

title: Quark
subtitle: A kind of fermion that experiences the strong interaction and carries fractional electric charge

title: Lepton
subtitle: A kind of fermion that does not experience the strong interaction

title: Antiquark
subtitle: The antiparticle of a quark

title: Antilepton
subtitle: The antiparticle of a lepton

title: Positron
subtitle: (Anti-electron)

title: Boson
subtitle: A kind of elementary particle that are typically force carriers or associated with fundamental fields, obey Bose-Einstein statistics, and have integer spin

title: Gauge Boson
subtitle: A kind of boson that mediates fundamental forces, spin-1

title: W\(^+\) Boson
subtitle: a

title: W\(^-\) Boson
subtitle: a

title: Z\(^0\) Boson
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 1 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 2 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 3 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 4 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 5 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 6 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 7 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Gluon (Type 8 of 8)
subtitle: a

title: Scalar Boson
subtitle: A kind of boson with spin-0

title: Composite Particle
subtitle: A subatomic particle composed of two or more elementary particles bound together by fundamental forces.

title: Hadron
subtitle: A composite particle that interacts via the strong nuclear force, composed of quarks and/or antiquarks, and gluons.

title: Baryon
subtitle: A type of hadron which is a fermion, typically composed of three quarks (qqq) or three antiquarks (antibaryon, \(\bar{q}\bar{q}\bar{q}\)).

title: Nucleon
subtitle: A baryon that is a primary constituent of atomic nuclei.

title: Proton
subtitle: A stable nucleon with a positive electric charge, composed of two up quarks and one down quark (uud).

title: Neutron
subtitle: A nucleon with no net electric charge, composed of one up quark and two down quarks (udd); stable within nuclei but decays when free.

title: Hyperon
subtitle: A baryon containing one or more strange quarks, but no charm, bottom, or top quarks; typically heavier than nucleons.

title: Lambda Baryon (\(\Lambda\))
subtitle: A hyperon with isospin 0 (e.g., \(\Lambda^0\) (uds)).

title: Sigma Baryon (\(\Sigma\))
subtitle: A hyperon with isospin 1 (e.g., \(\Sigma^+\) (uus), \(\Sigma^0\) (uds), \(\Sigma^-\) (dds)).

title: Xi Baryon (\(\Xi\))
subtitle: A hyperon containing two strange quarks (e.g., \(\Xi^0\) (uss), \(\Xi^-\) (dss)).

title: Omega Baryon (\(\Omega\))
subtitle: A hyperon containing three strange quarks (e.g., \(\Omega^-\) (sss)).

title: Charmed Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing one or more charm quarks.

title: Singly Charmed Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing one charm quark (e.g., \(\Lambda_c^+\) (udc), \(\Sigma_c\) (uuc, udc, ddc), \(\Xi_c\) (usc, dsc), \(\Omega_c^0\) (ssc)).

title: Doubly Charmed Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing two charm quarks (e.g., \(\Xi_{cc}^{++}\) (ccu), \(\Xi_{cc}^{+}\) (ccd)).

title: Triply Charmed Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing three charm quarks (e.g., \(\Omega_{ccc}^{++}\) (ccc)).

title: Bottom Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing one or more bottom quarks.

title: Singly Bottom Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing one bottom quark (e.g., \(\Lambda_b^0\) (udb), \(\Sigma_b\) (uub, udb, ddb), \(\Xi_b\) (usb, dsb), \(\Omega_b^-\) (ssb)).

title: Doubly Bottom Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing two bottom quarks (e.g., \(\Xi_{bb}^{0}\) (bbu), \(\Xi_{bb}^{-}\) (bbd)).

title: Triply Bottom Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing three bottom quarks (e.g., \(\Omega_{bbb}^-\) (bbb), hypothetical).

title: Mixed Heavy Flavor Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing a combination of charm and bottom quarks.

title: Charm-Bottom Baryon
subtitle: A baryon containing one charm quark and one bottom quark (e.g., \(\Xi_{bc}\) (ucb, dcb), \(\Omega_{bc}\) (scb)).

title: Charm-Charm-Bottom Baryon
subtitle: A baryon with two charm quarks and one bottom quark (e.g., \(\Omega_{ccb}\)).

title: Charm-Bottom-Bottom Baryon
subtitle: A baryon with one charm quark and two bottom quarks (e.g., \(\Omega_{cbb}\)).

title: Antibaryon
subtitle: The antiparticle of a baryon, composed of three antiquarks.

title: Antinucleon
subtitle: The antiparticle of a nucleon.

title: Antiproton (\(\bar{p}\))
subtitle: The antiparticle of a proton ( \(\bar{u}\bar{u}\bar{d}\) ).

title: Antineutron (\(\bar{n}\))
subtitle: The antiparticle of a neutron ( \(\bar{u}\bar{d}\bar{d}\) ).

title: Antihyperon
subtitle: The antiparticle of a hyperon (e.g., \(\bar{\Lambda}^0\), \(\bar{\Sigma}^+\), \(\bar{\Xi}^0\), \(\bar{\Omega}^+\)).

title: Meson
subtitle: A type of hadron which is a boson, typically composed of one quark and one antiquark (q\(\bar{q}\)).

title: Light Meson
subtitle: A meson composed of up, down, and/or strange quarks and antiquarks.

title: Pion (\(\pi\))
subtitle: The lightest type of meson (e.g., \(\pi^+\) (u\(\bar{d}\)), \(\pi^0\), \(\pi^-\) (d\(\bar{u}\))).

title: Kaon (K)
subtitle: A meson containing one strange quark or antiquark (e.g., \(K^+\) (u\(\bar{s}\)), \(K^0\) (d\(\bar{s}\))).

title: Eta Meson (\(\eta, \eta'\))
subtitle: Flavor-neutral light mesons (e.g., \(\eta\), \(\eta'(958)\)).

title: Rho Meson (\(\rho\))
subtitle: A short-lived vector meson (e.g., \(\rho(770)\)).

title: Omega Meson (\(\omega\))
subtitle: A short-lived, unflavored vector meson, distinct from the Omega baryon (e.g., \(\omega(782)\)).

title: Phi Meson (\(\phi\))
subtitle: A vector meson consisting primarily of a strange quark and strange antiquark pair (s\(\bar{s}\)) (e.g., \(\phi(1020)\)).

title: Other Light Meson Family
subtitle: Other light mesons often categorized by their spin, parity, and C-parity, such as f-mesons, a-mesons, and K* (vector kaon) mesons.

title: Heavy Quarkonium
subtitle: A flavorless meson composed of a heavy quark and its own antiquark.

title: Charmonium (c\(\bar{c}\))
subtitle: A meson made of a charm quark and a charm antiquark (e.g., J/\(\psi\), \(\psi(2S)\), \(\chi_c\)).

title: Bottomonium (b\(\bar{b}\))
subtitle: A meson made of a bottom quark and a bottom antiquark (e.g., \(\Upsilon(1S)\), \(\Upsilon(2S)\), \(\chi_b\)).

title: Heavy Flavor Meson (Open Flavor)
subtitle: A meson composed of one heavy quark (charm or bottom) and one lighter antiquark, or vice versa.

title: Charmed Meson (Open Charm)
subtitle: A meson containing one charm quark or antiquark, and a lighter antiquark or quark (e.g., D\(^0\) (c\(\bar{u}\)), D\(^+\) (c\(\bar{d}\)), D_s\(^+\) (c\(\bar{s}\)), D* mesons).

title: Bottom Meson (Open Bottom)
subtitle: A meson containing one bottom quark or antiquark, and a lighter antiquark or quark (e.g., B\(^0\) (d\(\bar{b}\)), B\(^+\) (u\(\bar{b}\)), B_s\(^0\) (s\(\bar{b}\)), B* mesons).

title: Bc Meson
subtitle: A meson composed of a bottom quark and a charm antiquark (b\(\bar{c}\)) or a charm quark and a bottom antiquark (c\(\bar{b}\)) (e.g., B_c\(^+\)).

title: Exotic Hadron
subtitle: A hadron that does not fit the traditional model of baryons (three quarks) or mesons (quark-antiquark).

title: Tetraquark
subtitle: An exotic meson composed of four quarks (typically two quarks and two antiquarks: qqq̄q̄).

title: Pentaquark
subtitle: An exotic baryon composed of five quarks (typically four quarks and one antiquark: qqqqq̄).

title: Glueball
subtitle: A hypothetical hadron composed primarily of gluons, with no valence quarks.

title: Hybrid Hadron
subtitle: A hypothetical hadron containing valence quarks/antiquarks and one or more excited gluons.

title: Atomic Nucleus
subtitle: A composite subatomic particle forming the core of an atom, typically composed of one or more protons and zero or more neutrons (collectively called nucleons), bound together by the residual strong force (nuclear force).

title: Protium Nucleus
subtitle: The nucleus of the most common isotope of hydrogen (\(^1\)H), consisting of a single proton. (This is the proton, in its role as a nucleus).

title: Deuteron
subtitle: The nucleus of deuterium (\(^2\)H), an isotope of hydrogen, composed of one proton and one neutron.

title: Triton
subtitle: The nucleus of tritium (\(^3\)H), an isotope of hydrogen, composed of one proton and two neutrons.

title: Helion (Helium-3 Nucleus)
subtitle: The nucleus of the helium-3 isotope (\(^3\)He), composed of two protons and one neutron.

title: Alpha Particle (Helium-4 Nucleus)
subtitle: The nucleus of the helium-4 isotope (\(^4\)He), composed of two protons and two neutrons.

title: Light Atomic Nucleus (General Category)
subtitle: An atomic nucleus with a relatively small number of nucleons (e.g., mass number A < 20), often characterized by specific stability properties.

title: Medium-Mass Atomic Nucleus (General Category)
subtitle: An atomic nucleus with an intermediate number of nucleons (e.g., approximately 20 \(\le\) A \(\le\) 100).

title: Heavy Atomic Nucleus (General Category)
subtitle: An atomic nucleus with a large number of nucleons (e.g., A > 100).

title: Stable Atomic Nucleus (Property Based Category)
subtitle: An atomic nucleus that does not undergo radioactive decay, or decays with an extremely long half-life.

title: Unstable Atomic Nucleus (Radionuclide) (Property Based Category)
subtitle: An atomic nucleus that undergoes radioactive decay, transforming into another nuclide.

title: Exotic Atomic Nucleus (Composition/Structure Based Category)
subtitle: An atomic nucleus with an unusual proton-to-neutron ratio, structure, or composition compared to stable nuclei.

title: Hypernucleus
subtitle: An atomic nucleus that contains at least one hyperon in addition to nucleons.

title: Halo Nucleus
subtitle: An atomic nucleus with a compact core and one or more loosely bound nucleons forming a diffuse "halo" at a relatively large distance.

title: Superheavy Element Nucleus
subtitle: The nucleus of a superheavy element, typically with atomic number Z > 104, often characterized by short half-lives and unique decay modes.

title: Atom
subtitle: smallest unit of a chemical element.

title: Molecule
subtitle: group of atoms bonded together.

title: Bulk Phase
subtitle: macroscopic state of matter with uniform properties.

title: Solid
subtitle: retains a fixed shape and volume.

title: Liquid
subtitle: takes shape of container; fixed volume.

title: Gas
subtitle: takes shape and volume of container.

title: Plasma
subtitle: ionized gas with collective behavior.

title: Composite Material
subtitle: made from two or more constituent materials.

title: Physical Object
subtitle: bounded collections of substances

title: Natural Object
subtitle: exists independently of human creation.

title: Biological Organism
subtitle: a living physical entity.

title: Astronomical Body
subtitle: a naturally occurring physical entity in space.

title: Geological Formation
subtitle: natural accumulation of mineral matter.

title: Artificial Object
subtitle: created by human or intelligent agent.

title: Tool
subtitle: used to achieve a goal.

title: Machine
subtitle: device using power to perform tasks.

title: Building
subtitle: structure with walls and a roof.

title: Vehicle
subtitle: device used for transport.

title: Furniture
subtitle: movable objects for comfort or utility.

title: Clothing
subtitle: items worn on the body.

title: Physical Field
subtitle: spatially extended continuous entities

title: Gravitational Field
subtitle: region where mass experiences force.

title: Electromagnetic Field
subtitle: unified field of electric and magnetic effects.

title: Quantum Field
subtitle: fundamental entity in quantum field theory.

title: Scalar Field
subtitle: assigns scalar value to each point.

title: Vector Field
subtitle: assigns vector to each point.

title: Tensor Field
subtitle: assigns tensor to each point.

title: Physical System
subtitle: integrated assemblies of entities

title: Mechanical System
subtitle: concerned with motion, force, energy.

title: Thermal System
subtitle: concerned with heat and temperature.

title: Chemical System
subtitle: involves chemical reactions and substances.

title: Biological System
subtitle: network of interacting biological entities.

title: Electrical System
subtitle: involves flow of electric charge.

title: Optical System
subtitle: manipulates or detects light.

title: Ecological System
subtitle: community of organisms and environment.

title: Astronomical System
subtitle: collection of celestial objects gravitationally bound.

title: Physical Attribute
subtitle: inherent qualities or aspects of entities

title: Physical Property
subtitle: measurable attributes

title: Fundamental Quantity
subtitle: basic measurable quantity, not derived.

title: Derived Quantity
subtitle: quantity defined from fundamental quantities.

title: Material Property
subtitle: property inherent to a specific material.

title: Thermodynamic Property
subtitle: property related to heat, temperature, energy.

title: Electromagnetic Property
subtitle: property related to electric and magnetic fields.

title: Optical Property
subtitle: property describing interaction with light.

title: Energy Form
subtitle: specific manifestations of energy

title: Kinetic Energy
subtitle: energy of motion.

title: Potential Energy
subtitle: stored energy based on position or state.

title: Thermal Energy
subtitle: energy associated with temperature of substance.

title: Chemical Energy
subtitle: energy stored in chemical bonds.

title: Nuclear Energy
subtitle: energy stored in atomic nuclei.

title: Radiant Energy
subtitle: energy of electromagnetic waves (e.g., light).

title: Physical State
subtitle: distinct conditions or configurations

title: Solid State
subtitle: rigid structure, definite shape and volume.

title: Liquid State
subtitle: definite volume, takes container shape.

title: Gas State
subtitle: no definite shape or volume.

title: Plasma State
subtitle: ionized gas, behaves collectively under fields.

title: Metastable State
subtitle: non-equilibrium state with long lifetime.

title: Excited State
subtitle: higher energy state than ground state.

title: Ground State
subtitle: lowest energy state of system.

title: Physical Structure
subtitle: recurring spatial arrangements

title: Crystalline Structure
subtitle: highly ordered atomic/molecular arrangement.

title: Cellular Structure
subtitle: organized assembly of cells in biology.

title: Network Structure
subtitle: interconnected nodes and edges.

title: Fractal Structure
subtitle: self-similar patterns at different scales.

title: Molecular Structure
subtitle: arrangement of atoms within a molecule.

title: Architectural Structure
subtitle: designed arrangement of building components.

title: Physical Dynamics
subtitle: active behaviors and changes

title: Physical Interaction
subtitle: force-mediated couplings

title: Gravitational Interaction
subtitle: attractive force between masses.

title: Electromagnetic Interaction
subtitle: force between charged particles.

title: Strong Nuclear Interaction
subtitle: force binding nucleons in nucleus.

title: Weak Nuclear Interaction
subtitle: force involved in radioactive decay.

title: Frictional Interaction
subtitle: force opposing relative motion.

title: Elastic Interaction
subtitle: interaction where entities deform and return.

title: Physical Process
subtitle: time-directed sequences of change

title: Mechanical Process
subtitle: process involving forces and motion.

title: Thermal Process
subtitle: process involving heat transfer or temperature change.

title: Chemical Process
subtitle: process involving chemical reactions.

title: Nuclear Process
subtitle: process involving changes in atomic nuclei.

title: Phase Transition Process
subtitle: process changing physical state of matter.

title: Biological Process
subtitle: process occurring within living organisms.

title: Geological Process
subtitle: process shaping the Earth's surface/interior.

title: Physical Phenomenon
subtitle: observable manifestations

title: Wave Phenomenon
subtitle: behavior of waves (e.g., interference, diffraction).

title: Quantum Phenomenon
subtitle: behavior at atomic/subatomic scale.

title: Electromagnetic Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving electric and magnetic fields.

title: Thermal Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving heat and temperature.

title: Optical Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving light and vision.

title: Acoustic Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving sound and vibration.

title: Information Carrier
subtitle: substrates and channels that hold or convey information

title: Transmission Channel
subtitle: a pathway for information in transit

title: Digital Communication Channel
subtitle: e.g. fiber-optic link, Ethernet

title: Analog Communication Channel
subtitle: e.g. radio wave, analog audio line

title: Biological Communication Channel
subtitle: e.g. neural spike train, DNA messaging

title: Storage Medium
subtitle: a physical or virtual substrate for stored information

title: Physical Storage Medium
subtitle: e.g. paper, magnetic tape, optical disc

title: Solid-State Storage Medium
subtitle: e.g. SSD, flash memory

title: Biological Storage Medium
subtitle: e.g. DNA store, neural pattern

title: Mental
subtitle: The realm of mind, encompassing consciousness, cognition, affect, and volition

title: Mental State
subtitle: a distinct condition or mode of the mind or subjective experience

title: Affective State
subtitle: a state of feeling, mood, or emotional experience

title: Emotion
subtitle: A relatively brief, intense, and often specific affective state, typically involving physiological arousal, expressive behaviors, and conscious experience, often triggered by a particular internal or external stimulus or event.

title: Joy
subtitle: An emotion characterized by intense feelings of elation, pleasure, or delight, often in response to a specific positive event or realization.

title: Happiness
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a more general and sustained state of contentment, satisfaction, and positive well-being.

title: Sadness
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of loss, disadvantage, sorrow, or helplessness.

title: Anger
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of displeasure, antagonism, or hostility, often resulting from perceived provocation, hurt, or threat.

title: Fear
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of apprehension, dread, or alarm, typically triggered by perceived danger or threat.

title: Surprise
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a brief state of astonishment or wonder, typically elicited by an unexpected event.

title: Disgust
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of revulsion or strong disapproval, often in response to something offensive, distasteful, or contaminating.

title: Interest
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a feeling of engagement, focused attention, and concern towards a stimulus or subject, often due to its perceived relevance or importance.

title: Curiosity
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a strong desire to know, learn, or explore something new, unknown, or intriguing, often motivating investigation.

title: Love (Emotional State)
subtitle: A complex emotion characterized by deep affection, care, attachment, and often intimacy towards another being or entity. (Distinguished from love as a broader sentiment or relationship construct).

title: Shame
subtitle: A self-conscious emotion characterized by painful feelings of humiliation or distress caused by the consciousness of wrong or foolish behavior, or a perceived inadequacy.

title: Guilt
subtitle: A self-conscious emotion characterized by feelings of culpability or remorse for a perceived offense, transgression, or wrongdoing.

title: Pride
subtitle: A self-conscious emotion characterized by feelings of deep pleasure or satisfaction derived from one's own achievements, qualities, or possessions, or those of someone with whom one is closely associated.

title: Contempt
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of disdain, scorn, or disrespect for someone or something regarded as worthless or inferior.

title: Gratitude
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of thankfulness and appreciation in response to receiving a benefit from another.

title: Hope
subtitle: An emotion characterized by an expectation and desire for a certain positive outcome.

title: Jealousy
subtitle: A complex emotion characterized by feelings of insecurity, fear, and concern over an anticipated loss of something of personal value, particularly in the context of a human relationship.

title: Envy
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a painful or resentful awareness of an advantage enjoyed by another, coupled with a desire to possess the same advantage.

title: Frustration
subtitle: An emotion experienced when an anticipated goal or action is blocked or prevented.

title: Relief
subtitle: An emotion experienced upon the removal of distress, pain, or anxiety.

title: Regret
subtitle: An emotion characterized by sadness, repentance, or disappointment over something that has happened or been done, especially a loss or missed opportunity.

title: Awe
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of reverential respect mixed with fear or wonder, often elicited by something perceived as vast, sublime, or powerful.

title: Amusement
subtitle: An emotion characterized by finding something funny or entertaining, often accompanied by smiling or laughter.

title: Excitement
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of great enthusiasm and eagerness.

title: Contentment
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a state of peaceful satisfaction and ease.

title: Compassion
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a deep awareness of and empathy for the suffering of another, coupled with a strong motivation to alleviate that suffering.

title: Sympathy
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of concern, care, and understanding for someone else's sorrow or misfortune, acknowledging their distress.

title: Mood
subtitle: A prolonged, less intense, and more diffuse affective state that is not necessarily tied to a specific object or event, often coloring one's overall subjective experience and outlook for a period.

title: Euthymic Mood
subtitle: A relatively stable mood state characterized by a sense of normalcy, calmness, and absence of marked elevation or depression. (Baseline mood).

title: Elevated Mood / Euphoric Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by an exaggerated feeling of well-being, elation, or happiness, often disproportionate to circumstances.

title: Dysphoric Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by general feelings of unease, dissatisfaction, unhappiness, or sadness.

title: Depressed Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, emptiness, hopelessness, or loss of interest or pleasure. (Can be a symptom of a disorder or a standalone mood state).

title: Irritable Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a propensity to be easily annoyed, angered, or agitated.

title: Anxious Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by sustained feelings of apprehension, worry, nervousness, or unease, often about an impending event or something with an uncertain outcome.

title: Apathetic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern; indifference.

title: Expansive Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by unceasing and indiscriminate enthusiasm for interpersonal, sexual, or occupational interactions, often associated with an overestimation of one's importance or capabilities.

title: Calm Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by tranquility, serenity, and freedom from agitation or disturbance.

title: Tense Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by feelings of mental or nervous strain, stress, or suspense.

title: Energetic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by having or showing great activity or vitality.

title: Fatigued Mood / Lethargic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a lack of energy and enthusiasm, weariness, or sluggishness.

title: Sensory State
subtitle: a state of subjective experience derived from sensory input

title: Visual Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from visual input.

title: Auditory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from sound input.

title: Olfactory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from smell input.

title: Gustatory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from taste input.

title: Somatosensory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from bodily senses (touch, pain).

title: Vestibular Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from balance/orientation system.

title: Interoceptive Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience of internal bodily states.

title: Mental Process
subtitle: an operation or sequence of changes occurring in the mind

title: Cognitive Process
subtitle: a mental operation involved in acquiring, processing, or using knowledge and information

title: Perceptual Process
subtitle: interpreting sensory information.

title: Attentional Process
subtitle: selecting and focusing on stimuli.

title: Sustained Attention
subtitle: maintaining focus over time.

title: Selective Attention
subtitle: focusing on specific stimuli among others.

title: Attentional Lapse
subtitle: temporary failure of attention.

title: Memory Process
subtitle: an operation involved in encoding, storing, or retrieving information

title: Episodic Memory Process
subtitle: processing personal events with context.

title: Semantic Memory Process
subtitle: processing general world knowledge.

title: Procedural Memory Process
subtitle: processing skills and habits.

title: Autobiographical Memory Process
subtitle: processing personal past events.

title: Thinking Process
subtitle: manipulating information to reason, solve problems.

title: Reasoning Process
subtitle: drawing conclusions from information.

title: Learning Process
subtitle: acquiring new knowledge or skills.

title: Metacognitive Process
subtitle: thinking about one's own thinking.

title: Time-Perception Process
subtitle: subjective experience of duration.

title: Interval-Timing Process
subtitle: judging duration of intervals.

title: Social Cognitive Process
subtitle: a cognitive process involved in understanding and interacting with the social world

title: Theory of Mind
subtitle: understanding others' mental states.

title: Empathy (as a cognitive process component)
subtitle: cognitively understanding others' feelings.

title: Social Attribution Process
subtitle: explaining others' behavior.

title: Stereotyping Process
subtitle: applying generalized beliefs to groups.

title: Volitional Process
subtitle: a mental operation related to will, motivation, and goal-directed action

title: Motivational Process
subtitle: driving behavior towards goals.

title: Intention Formation Process
subtitle: developing plans to act.

title: Decision-Making Process
subtitle: choosing among options.

title: Self-Control Process
subtitle: regulating impulses and behavior.

title: Executive Function Process
subtitle: higher-level cognitive control processes.

title: Communicative Process
subtitle: a mental operation involved in the exchange of information or meaning

title: Language Production Process
subtitle: generating spoken or written language.

title: Language Comprehension Process
subtitle: understanding spoken or written language.

title: Inner Speech Process
subtitle: internal verbal thinking.

title: Nonverbal Communication Process
subtitle: communicating without words.

title: Social Communicative Interaction Process
subtitle: exchanging meaning in social contexts.

title: Developmental Process
subtitle: a mental operation reflecting change over time in mental capacities or functioning

title: Cognitive Development Process
subtitle: changes in thinking over lifespan.

title: Expertise Acquisition Process
subtitle: developing high proficiency in skill.

title: Cognitive Aging Process
subtitle: changes in cognition with age.

title: Creative Process
subtitle: a mental operation involved in generating novel and valuable ideas or products

title: Divergent Thinking Process
subtitle: generating multiple possible solutions.

title: Convergent Thinking Process
subtitle: finding single best solution.

title: Problem-Solving Process
subtitle: finding solutions to obstacles.

title: Emotional Regulation Process
subtitle: a mental operation to influence the experience or expression of emotion

title: Mental Content
subtitle: information, beliefs, or representations held within the mind

title: Mental Representation
subtitle: a mental structure that stands for something else

title: Mental Imagery
subtitle: a sensory-like representation generated internally, often resembling the experience of actual perception.

title: Sensory Modality-Specific Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery primarily associated with a particular sensory system.

title: Visual Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on sight, including objects, scenes, and spatial layouts.

title: Eidetic Imagery
subtitle: unusually vivid, detailed, and persistent visual recall, akin to "photographic memory."

title: Fantastical Visual Imagery
subtitle: visual imagery of non-existent or impossible scenes (e.g., hallucinations, dreams).

title: Auditory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on sound, including voices, music, environmental sounds.

title: Musical Imagery
subtitle: internal experience of melodies, harmonies, and rhythms.

title: Verbal Imagery
subtitle: internal "hearing" of words or speech.

title: Olfactory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on smell (e.g., recalling the scent of coffee).

title: Gustatory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on taste (e.g., recalling the taste of lemon).

title: Somatosensory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on bodily sensations.

title: Tactile Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of touch sensations (e.g., texture, pressure).

title: Kinesthetic Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of bodily movement or position (e.g., imagining walking).

title: Thermal Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of temperature sensations (e.g., imagining warmth or cold).

title: Pain Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of pain sensations.

title: Mental Model
subtitle: an internal, dynamic representation of a system, situation, or phenomenon that allows for understanding, prediction, and explanation.

title: Domain-Specific Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model tailored to a particular area of knowledge or activity.

title: System Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model of how a particular physical or abstract system operates (e.g., a car engine, computer software).

title: Functional Mental Model
subtitle: represents the purpose and intended behavior of system components.

title: Structural Mental Model
subtitle: represents the physical or logical arrangement of system components.

title: Process Mental Model
subtitle: represents the sequence of operations or transformations within a system.

title: Task Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model of how to perform a specific task, including goals, steps, and required resources.

title: Social Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model of social interactions, group dynamics, or societal structures.

title: Other Minds Model (Theory of Mind)
subtitle: model of the beliefs, intentions, and desires of other individuals.

title: Group Dynamics Model
subtitle: model of how groups behave and interact.

title: Situational Model
subtitle: a dynamic mental model representing the current state and likely future states of an immediate environment or context.

title: Current State Model
subtitle: represents what is happening now in the situation.

title: Environmental State Model
subtitle: model of the physical surroundings and their properties (e.g., weather, terrain).

title: System State Model (Situational Context)
subtitle: model of the current configuration and operational status of relevant systems within the situation.

title: Agent State Model (Situational Context)
subtitle: model of the current internal states (e.g., location, actions, immediate goals) of other agents involved in the situation.

title: Future State Model
subtitle: represents predictions or projections of how the situation will evolve.

title: Trend Extrapolation Model
subtitle: projection based on observed patterns or trajectories (e.g., speed and direction of a moving object).

title: Event Prediction Model
subtitle: anticipation of specific future events or outcomes (e.g., a collision, a change in system status).

title: Consequence Projection Model
subtitle: mental simulation of the potential results of one's own actions or external events on the situation.

title: Explanatory Model
subtitle: represents the underlying reasons, causes, or constraints for the current situation.

title: Causal Attribution Model
subtitle: understanding why events or behaviors occurred within the situation.

title: Anomaly Explanation Model
subtitle: providing a reason or rationale for unexpected or unusual observations in the situation.

title: Conceptual Category
subtitle: a mental grouping of distinct entities (objects, events, ideas) based on shared properties, relationships, or functions.

title: Formation Basis of Category
subtitle: how a conceptual category is acquired or structured.

title: Natural Kind Concept
subtitle: a conceptual category referring to naturally occurring groupings whose members share intrinsic properties (e.g., "bird," "water," "tree").

title: Artifact Concept
subtitle: a conceptual category referring to human-made objects, often defined by their intended function or design (e.g., "chair," "hammer").

title: Ad Hoc Category
subtitle: a conceptual category formed temporarily for a specific purpose or context, often lacking stable defining features (e.g., "things to take on a picnic," "things that could fall on your head").

title: Goal-Derived Category
subtitle: a conceptual category whose members serve a common goal or satisfy a particular function, regardless of their superficial similarity (e.g., "things to lose weight," "things to escape a fire").

title: Structure of Category
subtitle: the internal organization or representation of a conceptual category.

title: Prototype Theory of Concepts
subtitle: categories are structured around a central, idealized member (the prototype) that best exemplifies the category's features, with graded membership.

title: Exemplar Theory of Concepts
subtitle: categories are represented by a collection of individual stored examples (exemplars) of category members, with new items compared to these stored examples.

title: Theory-Theory of Concepts
subtitle: categories are structured by miniature, implicit theories or explanatory frameworks that guide understanding and classification.

title: Classical View of Concepts
subtitle: categories are defined by a set of necessary and sufficient conditions that all members must possess (less commonly held in modern cognitive science).

title: Belief
subtitle: a mental representation of a proposition or state of affairs accepted by an individual as true or factual.

title: Epistemic Status of Belief
subtitle: classification based on the justification or source of knowledge.

title: Justified Belief
subtitle: a belief held with adequate evidence, reasoning, or support.

title: Empirically Justified Belief
subtitle: based on sensory experience or observation.

title: Logically Justified Belief
subtitle: based on principles of reason or formal deduction.

title: Testimonially Justified Belief
subtitle: based on reliable testimony from others.

title: Unjustified Belief
subtitle: a belief held without adequate evidence or reason.

title: False Belief
subtitle: a belief that does not correspond to reality.

title: True Belief
subtitle: a belief that corresponds to reality.

title: Form of Belief
subtitle: how the belief is held or expressed mentally.

title: Propositional Belief
subtitle: a belief that can be expressed as a declarative statement or proposition (e.g., "It is raining").

title: Dispositional Belief
subtitle: a tendency to act or feel as if a proposition is true, even if not consciously affirmed or considered at every moment.

title: Occurrent Belief
subtitle: a belief that is actively present in conscious thought at a given moment.

title: Content Domain of Belief
subtitle: the subject matter of the belief.

title: Factual Belief
subtitle: belief concerning objective states of affairs (e.g., "Water boils at 100°C").

title: Value Belief
subtitle: belief concerning what is good, bad, right, or wrong (e.g., "Honesty is important").

title: Self-Belief
subtitle: belief about one's own characteristics, abilities, or identity.

title: Social Belief
subtitle: belief about social groups, norms, or societal structures.

title: Centrality of Belief
subtitle: the importance or interconnectedness of a belief within an individual's belief system.

title: Core Belief
subtitle: fundamental, often unconscious, and highly resistant to change; forms the foundation of one's worldview.

title: Peripheral Belief
subtitle: less central, more easily changed beliefs that are often derived from or supported by core beliefs.

title: Desire
subtitle: a mental representation of a desired outcome, state, or object, accompanied by a motivational pull towards its realization.

title: Origin/Nature of Desire
subtitle: classification based on the source or fundamental drive.

title: Basic Desire (Primary/Biological)
subtitle: fundamental, often instinctual desires related to survival and well-being (e.g., for food, water, sleep, safety, procreation).

title: Acquired Desire (Secondary/Learned)
subtitle: desires that are learned or developed through experience, culture, or social interaction (e.g., for money, fame, knowledge).

title: Functional Role of Desire
subtitle: how the desire relates to other goals or outcomes.

title: Instrumental Desire
subtitle: a desire for something as a means to achieve another, more ultimate desire or goal.

title: Terminal Desire (Intrinsic)
subtitle: a desire for something as an end in itself, valued for its own sake.

title: Awareness of Desire
